I appreciate this video as I do all your videos, but you kinda got it wrong on this one. You say (at 5:11) that your "image flips as you move back and forth across the focal point." This isn't correct, and people can test it out. You can find the focal point of a mirror by seeing where it focuses something far away, like the sun or a distant tree, etc. If you then put your face at that spot (indoors, etc - don't burn yourself!), you'll see a nice image of your face that will be upright and it will look about twice as big as it would if the mirror were flat. The point where it will get blurry and flip over will be when you move to TWICE the focal point distance. (Try it) The image when you're at the focal point will be both very large and very far away, but it will only appear about twice the size of you (this is called the angular magnification.)

We all sometimes make the mistake of letting what we think should happen distract us from noticing what's really happening. (Derek's thesis is kind of on this idea.) The idea that the image gets blurry and flips when we stand at the focal point sounds sensible, but it's just not what actually happens. It's a common misconception that because the rays go out parallel there can't be an image, but if you remember that each point on your face gets mapped to a unique angle, you realize why you can still see an image when you stand at the focal point.

Thanks again for the great videos. I look forward to the next one.

Could you please explain virtual mirror in more detail?

If we think of the reflective surface as part of a sphere, it seems to me that the "switching point" comes when you are near its centre. Lets put your eye AT the centre of this sphere, then, as you look, the whole view will be filled up with an image your eye! Any ray of light leaving your eye will bounce right back at it - all radii from the centre of a sphere meet its surface at right angles.
If you move away from the part of the mirror you are looking at (or you make the mirror more sharply concave), the image of your eye will move closer to the mirror and you will see it upside down and shrinking.
If you move nearer to the mirror (or make the mirror more nearly flat or eventually convex) the image you will see will be the right way up. To start with, the image you'll see will be bigger than you but getting smaller. The image will be the same size as you are when the mirror is flat. Beyond that point, as the mirror becomes convex, the image will be smaller than you.
The focal distance of a mirror is half its radius. (f = r/2). Then if u and v are the distance from the mirror of the object and its image in the mirror, the following "lens" formula hold true. 1/f = 1/v + 1/u. However you have to get the signs of the values right!!

Before watching the rest of the video (stopped at 1:14), I will say the image of your face will appear to become almost infinitely large in the transition from upside down to right side up. This can be solved from the lens equation you learn in some physics or any optics classes. As you push in the spoon, the focal length becomes longer and reaches your face. At that point, all rays coming from a point on your face reflect parallel and appears infinitely far. At least in the simple model. After that, your face becomes right side up and gets smaller.
